@graph.d3f:definition: A decoy service, system, or environment, that is connected to the enterprise network, and simulates or emulates certain functionality to the network, without exposing full access to a production system.
@graph.rdfs:label: Connected Honeynet

@graph.d3f:definition: A Decoy Environment comprises hosts and networks for the purposes of deceiving an attacker.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy Environment

@graph.d3f:definition: A file created for the purposes of deceiving an adversary.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy File

@graph.d3f:definition: Deploying a network resource for the purposes of deceiving an adversary.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy Network Resource

@graph.d3f:definition: A Decoy Object is created and deployed for the purposes of deceiving attackers.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy Object

@graph.d3f:definition: Establishing a fake online identity to misdirect, deceive, and or interact with adversaries.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy Persona

@graph.d3f:definition: Issuing publicly released media to deceive adversaries.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy Public Release

@graph.d3f:definition: An authentication token created for the purposes of deceiving an adversary.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy Session Token

@graph.d3f:definition: A Credential created for the purpose of deceiving an adversary.
@graph.rdfs:label: Decoy User Credential

@graph.d3f:definition: The practice of setting decoys in a production environment to entice interaction from attackers.
@graph.rdfs:label: Integrated Honeynet

@graph.d3f:definition: An environment created for the purpose of attracting attackers and eliciting their behaviors that is not connected to any production enterprise systems.
@graph.rdfs:label: Standalone Honeynet

@graph.d3f:definition: The deceive tactic is used to advertise, entice, and allow potential attackers access to an observed or controlled environment.
@graph.rdfs:label: Deceive
